tool.name: NGS-QC Generator
tool.description: - A quality control system for profiles obtained by ChIP sequencing

param.name: nreplicates
param.label: Number of replicates
param.help: Generate up the three replicates of the QC assay. Useful to evaluate to potential variability among computed QC indicators

param.name: nodup
param.label: Exclude clonal (PCR Duplicates) reads
param.help: Use this option if you want to remove clonal reads.

param.name: nobgs
param.label: Exclude background (noise) reads
param.help: Uncheck this option if you want to disable the background subtraction.

param.name: lowres
param.label: Resolution (bp)
param.help: Used for local genomic regions displayed within the report

param.name: target
param.label: Target molecule (Optional)
param.help: When provided, the report will contain an extra page with a scatter-plot showing a comparison of the evaluated dataset's quality with those hosted in the NGS-QC database

tool.help:
**What it does**
Comparative analysis between Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) generated profiles, like ChIP-seq, RNA-seq, GRO-seq, MeDIP-seq, etc; requires prior characterization of their degree of technical similarity.
NGS-Q/C Generator infers global and local quality indicators based on a stand-alone approach; e.i avoiding the necessity of further wet-lab efforts. This computational approach evaluates the distribution of the sequencing reads associated to a particular NGS profile and this for distinct sampled populations.
Specifically, the total and uniquely aligned mapped reads (TMRs) are randomly sampled at three different densities; namely 90%, 70% and 50% (described here as s90, s70 and s50 respectively). Then, the genome-wide distribution of the sampled reads population is evaluated in the context of 500bp bins covering the genome of interest.
Further information and a tutorial how to analyze sequencing profiles with NGS-QC Generator, can be found here_.
.. _here: http://igbmc.fr/Gronemeyer_NGS_QC
-----
**Running time:**
It takes NGS-QC Generator around 5 minutes to analyze profiles smaller than 500Mb. For larger profiles, running time takes longer (e.g. 10 minutes for 1Gb profiles).
-----
**Background noise bias:**
Background noise is unavoidable in ChIP-seq profiling but the ratio/intensity can vary for different datasets due to differences in antibody specificity, depth of sequencing and occasionally due to partial misalignment.
Reads considered as background could bias the QC indicators calculation and QC-STAMP prediction. In order to exclude background noise while calculating the RCI/bin, we have incorporated a Poisson distribution-based model to estimate the background level threshold.
From the Poisson distribution, a value (intensity cutoff) is estimated and is subtracted from all the bins while calculating RCI.
-----
**Clonal reads bias:**
Clonal reads (PCR duplicates) are unavoidable in ChIP-Seq. In most cases, clonal reads are produced by PCR amplification during sequencing library preparation. Nevertheless, in certain cases, clonal reads may originate from the procedure used to fragment the chromatin prior sequencing and cannot be addressed as PCR duplicates per se.
